Mournfull Muses, sorrowes minions,</br>Dwelling in despaires opinions,</br>Yee that never thought invented,</br>How a heart may be contented</br>(But in torments alle distressed,</br>Hopelesse how to be redressed,</br>All with howling and with crying,</br>Live in a continuall dying)</br>Sing a Dirge on Spencers death,</br>Till your soules be out of breath.

Bidde the Dunces keepe their dennes,</br>And the Poets breake their pennes:</br>Bidde the Sheepheards shed their teares,</br>And the Nymphes go teare their haires:</br>Bidde the Schollers leave their reeding,</br>And prepare their hearts to bleeding:</br>Bidde the valiant and the wise,</br>Full of sorrowes fill their eyes;</br>All for griefe, that he is gone,</br>Who did grace them every one.

Fairy Queene, shew fairest Queene,</br>How her faire in thee is seene.</br>Sheepheards Calender set downe,</br>How to figure best a clowne.</br>As for Mother Hubberts tale,</br>Cracke the nut, and take the shale:</br>And for other workes of worth,</br>(All too good to wander forth)</br>Grieve that ever you were wrot,</br>And your Author be forgot.

Farewell Arte of Poetry,</br>Scorning idle foolery:</br>Farewell true conceited reason,</br>Where was never thought of treason:</br>Farewell judgement, with invention,</br>To describe a hearts intention:</br>Farewell wit, whose sound and sense</br>Shewe a Poets excellence:</br>Farewell all in one togither,</br>And, with Spencers garland, wither.

And, if any Graces live,</br>That will vertue honour give,</br>Let them shewe their true affection,</br>In the depth of griefes perfection,</br>In describing forth her glory,</br>When she is all most deepely sory;</br>That they all may wish to heere,</br>Such a song, and such a quier,</br>As, with all the woes they have,</br>Follow Spencer to his grave.</br>
